meaning_mnemonic: You're sitting on your <radical>stool</radical> <kanji>again</kanji>!!?
reading_mnemonic: Your friends are starting to worry about you, because you're always sitting on that stool. "What is the <reading>matter</reading> (また) with you?" they scream! You might want to imagine that all your friends have Jamaican or British accents to make this one fit a bit better!

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>leader</radical> of <radical>Korea</radical> is destined for <kanji>greatness</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>greatness</kanji> radiates off of the leader of Korea, so much so that you can hardly look. Just when you're about to close your eyes to shield them from the greatness, a great <reading>ea</reading>gle (い) soars over them, letting out a cry.

meaning_mnemonic: Take the <radical>street</radical> all the way to that <radical>geoduck</radical>, way up there. When you reach it, you will have made it to the <kanji>summit</kanji>. You <kanji>humbly</kanji> present the road to the geoduck and bow before it.
reading_mnemonic: You are at the top, the <kanji>summit</kanji> of everything! You <kanji>humbly</kanji> survey your surroundings from the top of the geoduck, only to see someone on the street, running toward you. It is Mrs. <reading>Chou</reading> (ちょう), and she looks angry.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>call</radical> radical and the <kanji>call</kanji> kanji are the same. This kanji can also mean <kanji>eat</kanji>, because why would you call someone if not to ask them to eat with you?!
reading_mnemonic: You are <kanji>call</kanji>ed to come <kanji>eat</kanji> by the <reading>Shou</reading>gun (しょう). He's been really impressed with you lately and he wants to chat over drinks, he says on the phone.

meaning_mnemonic: You run your <radical>fingers</radical> through your <radical>husband</radical>'s <radical>horns</radical>. His horns are what you love to <kanji>put between</kanji> your fingers.
reading_mnemonic: Why are your husband's horns what you always love to <kanji>put between</kanji> your fingers? Because he's a <reading>ho</reading>t <reading>ser</reading>geant (はさ)!

meaning_mnemonic: When a <radical>tree</radical> grows <radical>old</radical>, it will <kanji>wither</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: This <kanji>wither</kanji>ed tree's best friend is a human <reading>子</reading> (こ). Imagine the child hugging the tree.

meaning_mnemonic: If a <radical>tsunami</radical> hits a <radical>dollar</radical> the water will instantly start to <kanji>boil</kanji>!
reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>boil</kanji>ing water crashes onto the land and you realize your foot is in it! No, not one foot, both your <reading>foots</reading> (ふつ)! It hurts so much that you can't even remember the word for two foots.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>tsunami</radical> is coming, so you ask two <radical>Wolverine</radical>s to help you take your <radical>turkey</radical> out for a <kanji>wash</kanji>. Despite the obvious dangers, a giant wave is the only thing that'll wash a giant turkey, so you have no choice.
reading_mnemonic: To make sure your turkey won't get carried away by the tsunami while you <kanji>wash</kanji> it, you pin it down with a giant <reading>tack</reading> (たく). If you're washing a giant turkey inside a giant wave, only a giant tack will guarantee it doesn't get washed away.

meaning_mnemonic: There's a <radical>fire</radical> next to which you left some <radical>syrup</radical>, and it has all <kanji>dried up</kanji>! Put any liquid substance near fire and it will dry up actually, but syrup especially. It goes from being sticky and gooey and yummy to a pile of hard, dry sugar. Not so yummy.
reading_mnemonic: If you <kanji>dry up</kanji> syrup like this, you're removing its <reading>sou</reading>l (そう). Have you ever seen dry syrup before? No soul in that. In fact, you probably have no soul if you can dry out syrup like this without feeling bad about it.

meaning_mnemonic: You see <radical>horns</radical> on a <radical>lantern</radical> that can hold <radical>ten thousand</radical> <radical>drops</radical> of water sitting on the <radical>ground</radical>. You get closer and realize it's not a lantern, it's actually a <kanji>bottle</kanji>. The horns are like a weird handle, but it's definitely a bottle filled with water.
reading_mnemonic: Even though you're not the one who left this <kanji>bottle</kanji> here, you decide to do the right thing and throw it in the trash <reading>bin</reading> (びん). It's not right to leave a bottle just sitting on the ground, you know.

meaning_mnemonic: You have a <radical>plow</radical> and a (water) <radical>well</radical>. These are the two things you need in order to <kanji>plow</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: <kanji>Plow</kanji>ing all the fields are <reading>こう</reading>いちs. Not Emperor こういち. These are the こういち clones the government made, and now they're being put to use.

meaning_mnemonic: We must <radical>stop</radical> the <radical>moon</radical>. That, at least, we can come to an <kanji>agreement</kanji> on.
reading_mnemonic: "We have <kanji>agreement</kanji>," the world's leaders all say. "We will work together to stop the moon, and we have <kanji>agreement</kanji> on who we will follow, Emperor <reading>こう</reading>いち.

meaning_mnemonic: You ate the <radical>moon</radical> with a <radical>spoon</radical>, and then the <radical>sun</radical> too, but man were they high in <kanji>fat</kanji>! In fact, you wanted to eat them with chopsticks, but they were so greasy with fat that the spoon was your only option.
reading_mnemonic: Unbeknownst to you, the moon and sun contained as much <kanji>fat</kanji> as an entire adult <reading>shee</reading>p (し)! Why didn't you check the nutrition facts first???

meaning_mnemonic: If you look in a <radical>tiger</radical>'s <radical>stomach</radical> you'll find a bunch of <kanji>skin</kanji>. It's really gross but what else did you think you'd find? Everyone knows tigers can't digest the skin of the things it eats.
reading_mnemonic: The only person who would try to take <kanji>skin</kanji> from a tiger's stomach is a <reading>foo</reading>l (ふ). You'll probably get your head bitten off looking for skin that way.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>car</radical> that's <radical>lack</radical>ing is really <kanji>soft</kanji>. Cars need to be hard so that things like bugs and other cars wont hurt the people inside when you hit them. But if your car is lacking the hardness it needs, you'll have a really soft, useless car.
reading_mnemonic: This car is probably so <kanji>soft</kanji> because it's made entirely of <reading>naan</reading> (なん). Naan may be delicious, but it makes a really crappy car. No wonder it was so soft (and yummy).

meaning_mnemonic: If you <radical>mix</radical> a bunch of <radical>building</radical>s together, you have yourself a <kanji>suburb</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: "<kanji>Suburb</kanji>s are what we need!" says Emperor <reading>こう</reading>いち.

meaning_mnemonic: So my <radical>building</radical> has a big <radical>splinter</radical>, right in the <kanji>corner</kanji>. So what?
reading_mnemonic: That <kanji>corner</kanji> is dangerous, but what are you going to do, <reading>sue me</reading> (すみ)?

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>turkey</radical> sitting on a <radical>stool</radical> is something every ship has in its crow's nest. That's why the universal <kanji>ship counter</kanji> is a turkey on a stool. Not a crow.
reading_mnemonic: Once you become the best <kanji>ship counter</kanji> in the world everyone will think you are super <reading>sexy</reading> (せき)! Nothing is sexier than being able to count, and counting ships is the sexiest thing you can count.

meaning_mnemonic: Your <radical>clan</radical> is breaking <radical>ground</radical> and <radical>building</radical> your new <kanji>residence</kanji>. You're all working together to make you a new home!
reading_mnemonic: Your new <kanji>residence</kanji> is complete! You step closer and the smell of <reading>ta</reading>ter (てい) tots hits your nose. Someone is making you tater tots in your new residence. Wait, no they aren't. Your residence is MADE of tater tots! Thank you, clan!

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>buddy</radical> <radical>building</radical> is in the next <kanji>county</kanji>. If it was in your county then it wouldn't be a buddy, it would be a neighbor. You're aware of this building, but they aren't that close, so they're just a buddy.
reading_mnemonic: Your <kanji>county</kanji> is everything you can reach when shooting a <reading>gun</reading> (ぐん). If the bullet can't reach a building you know, it's a buddy building in another county.

meaning_mnemonic: If you use a <radical>sickle</radical> to kill a <radical>shrimp</radical> you'll need a really good <kanji>explanation</kanji> for yourself. What did that shrimp do to you? Why use a sickle? Well? What's your explanation?
reading_mnemonic: In your <kanji>explanation</kanji> you blame everything on <reading>Shaq</reading> (しゃく). He told you to do it! It's all Shaq's fault, you explain.

meaning_mnemonic: When the <radical>moon</radical> faces the right <radical>direction</radical>, the <kanji>fat</kanji> in the bodies of people and animals all gets drawn to the surface and we all look weirdly greasy for a little while. You probably knew that the moon exerts a pull on water, but I bet you didn't know it exerted a pull on fat too!
reading_mnemonic: As long as you're covered in <kanji>fat</kanji>, you might as well go <reading>bow</reading>ling (ぼう). Imagine how smoothly that bowling ball's going to roll after you slather it with some of this fat!

meaning_mnemonic: What would your <radical>mouth</radical> do if you got caught in a <radical>prison</radical> for <radical>legs</radical>? It'd probably get real <radical>big</radical> — in other words, it would <kanji>scream</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: You <kanji>scream</kanji> and scream and scream until a door bursts open. It's Genghis <reading>Khan</reading> (かん) and he looks mad. Apparently your screaming is bothering him and now he's gonna give you a real reason to scream.

meaning_mnemonic: Everyone knows that when a <radical>woman</radical> plays <radical>football</radical> she becomes a <kanji>princess</kanji>. Thats how princesses are made.
reading_mnemonic: Remember the word 姫? It means <kanji>princess</kanji> too. If you remember the ひめ from 姫, you'll be able to remember this one too.

meaning_mnemonic: You try to put your <radical>toe</radical> inside a <radical>shellfish</radical>, but it just won't open. That's because this shellfish has sworn an oath of <kanji>chastity</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: "<kanji>Chastity</kanji> is really important to me," the shellfish says. "But, maybe if you give me a <reading>ta</reading>ter (てい) tot, I'll change my mind."

meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Flowers</radical> that grow in a <radical>rice paddy</radical> only live to be <kanji>seedling</kanji>s. Once they sprout, they're plucked away to make room for more rice. Poor little seedlings.
reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>seedling</kanji>s try their best to blend in by referring to themselves as <reading>myou</reading> (みょう), you know, me and you combined. That's myou.

meaning_mnemonic: If you put two <radical>mustache</radical>s on either side of a <radical>tsunami</radical> it won't know which way to go and spin back and forth until it becomes a <kanji>whirlpool</kanji>. Mustaches are pretty gross, so I don't blame the tsunami for avoiding them.
reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>whirlpool</kanji> is huge, and it starts pulling things into itself. Oh no, is that my <reading>ca</reading>r (か)? Hey, wait! Whirlpool give my car back!

meaning_mnemonic: A person with <radical>horns</radical> has you on the <radical>ground</radical> and lets loose two <radical>poops</radical> over your <radical>heart</radical>. "<kanji>Mercy</kanji>! Mercy!" You cry, but the horned dude doesn't stop until there are two gross poops sitting on your heart. "M-mercy..." is the only thing you can think to say.
reading_mnemonic: As you shout "<kanji>Mercy</kanji>!" one more time, suddenly <reading>Je</reading>sus (じ) appears out of no where and punches the horned guy into the stratosphere. Jesus snaps his fingers and the poop is gone and you're off the ground. Your heart is safe.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>spirit</radical>s of the two <radical>tree</radical>s you destroyed with your <radical>jackhammer</radical> live on in the <kanji>collar</kanji> you made out of them.
reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>collar</kanji> keeps whispering, "<reading>Eri</reading>c (えり)!" into your ear. Your name isn't Eric (I mean it could be, in that case wow, weird, right?), so you assume one of the trees you killed was named Eric. But that's the only name you hear, so maybe they were both named Eric? It's weird.

meaning_mnemonic: You put <radical>flowers</radical> on your <radical>car</radical> and your <radical>scooter</radical>. The flowers you put on them are <kanji>lotus</kanji> flowers.
reading_mnemonic: You're putting a <kanji>lotus</kanji> on both your scooter and car because they are <reading>ren</reading>tals (れん).

meaning_mnemonic: There is a special type of meditation where you put a <radical>lid</radical> on your <radical>mouth</radical> and touch your <radical>forehead</radical> down to your <radical>legs</radical>. If you can do this pose, everything in life will become completely <kanji>clear</kanji>. Everything will clear out of your head too. You should try it.
reading_mnemonic: Your mind is as <kanji>clear</kanji> as a sparkling clear pond. On this pond you see yourself in a <reading>row</reading> (りょう) boat. A single row boat on the clear pond that is now your mind.

meaning_mnemonic: If you have an <radical>ear</radical> for the <radical>public</radical>'s <radical>heart</radical>, you must be very <kanji>wise</kanji>. You can understand everything the people want, and you know how to give it to them because you listen to their hearts so well.
reading_mnemonic: All of these <kanji>wise</kanji> things are stored in your <reading>sou</reading>l (そう), not your brain. That's where all of these kinds of intuitive feelings live.

meaning_mnemonic: If you want to have a <radical>tsunami</radical> at your <radical>wedding</radical>, you need to make sure you have it at the <kanji>bay</kanji>. Anywhere more inland, and the tsunami won't reach it in time.
reading_mnemonic: How did you get a tsunami to show up in the <kanji>bay</kanji> in the first place? By throwing a bunch of <reading>ura</reading>nium (うら) in there, of course! Its highly unstable nature can make any body of water, especially a calm bay, turn violent.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>dirt</radical> on the <radical>forehead</radical> of a <radical>pig</radical> makes a small <kanji>mound</kanji>. Picture it, if you will. A pig is rooting through the dirt. It lifts its head and there is a mound of dirt right on its forehead.
reading_mnemonic: The pig's forehead dirt <kanji>mound</kanji> keeps getting bigger until it's the size of <reading>two cars</reading> (つか)! Pigs are big, but you didn't think one could balance a mound the size of two cars on its forehead and not fall over.
